title: How to Accessorize a Deck

steps.headline: Set up extra deck chairs if you plan on hosting large get-togethers.
steps.description: A good rule of thumb is to provide enough seating for your minimum expected number of regular guests. That way, you can make sure that you have plenty of perches for everyone who feels like taking a load off. If space is a concern, consider going with a foldable, stackable, or collapsible style that you can put away easily after everyone goes home. Buying your patio furniture in sets can help you save a few dollars. In many cases, a pack of identical chairs costs less than one or two individual chairs in different styles.Tip: In a pinch, you can also simply relocate a few chairs from inside your home to your deck to make sure everyone has a place to sit.

steps.headline: Shop around for versatile modular outdoor furniture.
steps.description: Modular furniture is one of the hottest current trends in decorating. A good set of modular patio furniture will make it possible to set up your pieces in a way that allows you to make the best use of your entertaining space. Keep an eye out for tables, chairs, and benches with built-in storage compartments, which will also help you keep the clutter on your deck to a minimum. The term “modular” is used to describe pieces that can be grouped together in many different configurations.

steps.headline: Choose durable furniture built to withstand the elements.
steps.description: Pieces made from materials like recycled plastics, marine-grade polymers, and resins offer the most bang for your buck. These types of materials are strong, water-resistant, and impervious to stains, mildew, and insects. And, since they don’t require paint, you won’t have to worry about them peeling or cracking over the years. Powder-coated aluminum, stainless steel, and treated woods like teak and cedar also make good materials for outdoor furniture.

steps.headline: Be willing to spend a little extra for high-quality furniture.
steps.description: Shelling out for the good stuff is a wise investment. For a few hundred dollars, you can fill your outdoor space with items designed to hold up to years of use. Cheaper furniture, by contrast, tends to break down quickly, forcing you to spend money on repairs or replacements—money which will add up over time. Budget furniture is also typically less attractive and comfortable than items with higher price points, since it’s often thrown together in a hurry using cheap materials.

steps.headline: Put out potted plants to introduce some natural beauty.
steps.description: Head down to your local gardening center or plant nursery and bring home a few plants of a suitable size for your deck. Situate your selections in areas that look a little sparse, such as in corners and in between items of furniture, to accentuate your existing decor and make the most of your available space. Plants that produce lush foliage throughout the warmer months, like bacopa, petunias, and sweet potato vine, will provide the longest-lasting beauty. If you're not sure what will look best where, start with 4-5 small plants and space them out around your deck to keep them from looking too busy. You can then add more as needed to fill in any conspicuous gaps.

steps.headline: Group different-sized containers together for an attractive offset look.
steps.description: While you’re picking out your plants, purchase pots, planters, urns, and baskets in varying sizes. Arrange these containers into clusters around the focal points of your deck. Careful grouping will maximize space and create the illusion that your plants are larger and fuller than they really are. Check for a number on the product label or the container itself to find out its specific size. A #1 pot, for example, holds 1 gallon (3.8 L). Position the biggest containers in the back, with the smaller containers up front or off to one side. That way, everything will be plainly visible and your visitors will be able to take in the entire scene with a glance.

steps.headline: Establish a color theme for your plants.
steps.description: Bring together flowers like marigolds, lantanas, and geraniums that shine with passionate red, yellow, and orange hues to highlight warm tones. For more of a subdued look, opt for flowers with cooler colors, such as purple petunias or towering blue salvias. Choose shades that compliment the colors of your home. Blues, greens, and violets harmonize well with homes with cool-colored paint jobs. Similarly, warmer plants will pair up perfectly with yellow, dusty orange, or deep red exteriors.

steps.headline: Stick to low-maintenance plants if you'd prefer to minimize upkeep.
steps.description: Succulents, for instance, require little water or fertilization, and are resistant to most pests and diseases. Other plants capable of thriving with minimal attention include black-eyed Susans, dianthus, hostas, and fescue and other grasses. Loading up on plants like these will allow you to spend less time gardening and more time relaxing or entertaining guests. Even the most hands-off species come in a variety of magnificent shapes, sizes, and colors, which should make it easy to create one-of-a-kind arrangements with little effort.

steps.headline: Plant small trees around your deck to create a natural privacy fence.
steps.description: Look for trees that grow to heights of 10–15 ft (3.0–4.6 m), such as Spartan Junipers, Sky Pencil Hollies, and Emerald Green Thujas. Once these trees reach their full size, they'll screen your deck from prying eyes while also adding another layer of greenery around your property. Planting trees isn’t cheap. Make sure you have a big enough budget to justify the expense if you’re thinking about going in this direction.Tip: Sectioned privacy screens can be a more affordable alternative to a strategic treeline—single screens range in price from $50-100. You can browse different styles and designs at your local gardening or home improvement center.

steps.headline: Pile your furniture with extra pillows to make it more comfortable.
steps.description: If getting cozy is your goal, try layering your seating solutions with pillows and cushions intended for indoor use. Soft, natural materials feel the best to the touch, but keep in mind that you’ll need to put these away whenever it rains to avoid ruining them. It may also be a good idea to make blankets available for those unexpectedly brisk evenings. If you decide to accessorize with items that aren’t intended for outdoor use, keep a small storage container nearby where you can stash them quickly when the weather takes a turn for the worse.

steps.headline: Put down a weather-resistant rug to tie your deck decor together.
steps.description: Make sure the rug you get is made from a synthetic material, such as polyester, nylon, or acrylic. Unlike cotton and similar natural fibers, synthetics aren’t susceptible to mold and mildew. They also won’t fade when exposed to direct sunlight, meaning they’ll retain their original vibrant color season after season. Certain moisture-resistant natural fibers like bamboo, hemp, and seagrass are resilient enough to handle heat and moisture, but they’ll still deteriorate faster than synthetic alternatives. Stretch a tape measure around the square or rectangular section of your deck closest to the center to determine what size rug will look best in your space.

steps.headline: Hang some chic wall art to serve as a conversation starter.
steps.description:
Make use of the blank space on the exterior wall of your home by covering it with paintings, small sculptures, or other visually-interesting mounted pieces. Outdoor wall art is a unique touch that’s guaranteed to turn heads and make your home stand out. Place paintings and other traditional art behind glass in treated wood or stainless steel frames to prevent rotting and rusting. Hunt for pieces of architectural salvage art at your neighborhood antique store. Architectural salvage is ideal for making any drab deck more aesthetically-pleasing, as most pieces are weather-hardy and crafted for longevity. Examples of Architectural Salvage Pieces:
Antique glassReclaimed stone and tileOld lanterns and other lighting mechanisms

steps.headline: Add a fire pit to continue enjoying your deck as the weather cools.
steps.description: A standalone fire pit can make a charming addition to your deck, especially once fall arrives. Lay down a grid of paver stones or a heat-resistant fire mat on the surface of your deck to protect it from the heat. You can then begin shopping for a fire pit that fits your deck’s specific dimensions, as well as your own personal tastes. Before you begin comparing various models, consult your local building codes to find out whether it’s legal to add a fire pit to a deck where you live. To prevent potential fire-related accidents, select a nice central spot for your fire pit that’s as far away from your home itself as possible. If you would prefer something smaller in addition to or instead of a full fire pit, you could make a tabletop fire bowl.

text:
